hypotheses.text: This feature detects the token for the organ word “lung,” specifically the space-prefixed token “ lung” and the BPE continuation “ung” when “Lung” is capitalized at a line/sentence start. Prediction: Prompts containing “lung function,” “the lung is,” or title-case “Lung health” will show strong activation on the “ lung”/“ung” piece (>5), while adjacent words (e.g., “cancer,” “health”) remain ~0.

The collocation “lung cancer” boosts activation beyond isolated “lung,” with maxima when “Lung” begins a line/title. Prediction: “Lung cancer” at line start (“L” + “ung”) will yield higher activation (≈6.4–6.8) than “lung” in other contexts (≈5.5–6.5). Control: “lung function tests” should activate on “ lung” but somewhat lower than line-initial “Lung cancer.”

The feature does not activate on generic “-ung” substrings (e.g., “Hungary”), showing near-zero activation; there is insufficient evidence that it selectively targets the organ word “lung.”
  Explanation: Test “Hungary is in Europe.” showed max 0.0000 with 'Hung'=0.0000.

The feature shows only low activation on the token “ lung” when it appears after complex hyphenated modifiers in oncology phrases (e.g., “non-small-cell lung cancer”), indicating suppression in hyphenated contexts; no evidence yet for line-initial/title-case enhancement.
  Explanation: In “The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.” the maximal activation was 0.1406 at ' lung' (BOS=0.0000; others 0.0000), consistent with suppression to near-zero in hyphenated structures.

test_results.prompt: The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.
She was diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer.
They treat non small cell lung cancer.

analysis_history:
OBSERVATION:
- Pattern 1: The highest-activation token is consistently the subword corresponding to “lung”: either the space-prefixed token “ lung” (e.g., 6.500, 5.750, 5.594) or the BPE split “L” + “ung” when capitalized at line start (e.g., “ung” = 6.750, 6.438).
- Pattern 2: The collocate “cancer” is almost always adjacent to “lung,” but “cancer” tokens themselves show 0.000 activation across examples, indicating the feature targets “lung,” not “cancer.”
- Pattern 3: Structural positioning appears to modulate strength: line-initial, title-cased “Lung ...” with BPE “L” + “ung” shows very high activation (6.750); mid-sentence “ lung” also activates strongly (6.500, 5.750, 5.594), but can be 0.000 in some contexts (e.g., in “-cell lung cancer.” the “ lung” is 0.000 while a later line-initial “Lung” in the same buffer yields “ung” = 6.438).
- Pattern 4: Domain context is biomedical/oncology; enumerations and etiology statements still only light up “lung,” not neighboring disease/organ terms (e.g., “melanoma,” “kidney,” “cancer” all ~0.000).
- Common elements: Tokens “ lung” and “ung” (from “Lung”), frequent bigram “lung cancer,” medical/oncology context, title/line starts, enumerations of cancers, hyphenated modifiers preceding lung (e.g., “-cell lung cancer”).

[HYPOTHESIS LIST]:
Hypothesis_1: This feature detects the token for the organ word “lung,” specifically the space-prefixed token “ lung” and the BPE continuation “ung” when “Lung” is capitalized at a line/sentence start. Prediction: Prompts containing “lung function,” “the lung is,” or title-case “Lung health” will show strong activation on the “ lung”/“ung” piece (>5), while adjacent words (e.g., “cancer,” “health”) remain ~0.

Hypothesis_2: The collocation “lung cancer” boosts activation beyond isolated “lung,” with maxima when “Lung” begins a line/title. Prediction: “Lung cancer” at line start (“L” + “ung”) will yield higher activation (≈6.4–6.8) than “lung” in other contexts (≈5.5–6.5). Control: “lung function tests” should activate on “ lung” but somewhat lower than line-initial “Lung cancer.”

Hypothesis_3: The feature is selective to the stem “lung,” not generic “-ung” substrings. Words containing “ung” but not the organ (e.g., “young,” “among,” “plunge,” “fungus,” “Hungary”) will not activate strongly (expected ≈0.0–<0.5 on “ung”). Control: “breast cancer,” “kidney cancer,” or “melanoma” should also yield ≈0.0 on those tokens.

Hypothesis_4: Structural and morphological specificity: activation is enhanced for line-initial/title-case “Lung ...” and plain “lung” as head noun, but reduced/variable when embedded in complex hyphenations (e.g., “small-cell lung cancer,” “non-small-cell lung cancer”) or pluralized/synonymized. Prediction: 
- “Lung cancer kills ...” (line start) → high “ung” (~6.4–6.8).
- “... small-cell lung cancer ...” → “ lung” lower or possibly ~0–5 depending on context; hyphenated modifiers may suppress.
- “lungs” and “pulmonary” will show lower activation than singular “lung” (potentially near 0 for “pulmonary”).

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.0396
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: 'ung'=0.0396, ' health'=0.0000, ' matters'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
REFUTE. The hypothesis predicted strong activation (>5) on the “ung” piece for line-initial “Lung...”, but the observed activation on 'ung' is only 0.0396, effectively near zero. Adjacent tokens like ' health' are 0.0000 as expected, but the key prediction of strong activation on 'ung' did not occur.

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: REFUTED
Evidence: In "Lung health matters.", the maximal activation is 0.0396 at 'ung', far below the expected >5 for detecting the “lung” token, indicating the feature does not strongly detect “lung”/“Lung” in this context.

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.0396
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: 'ung'=0.0396, ' cancer'=0.0000, ' is'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
REFUTE. The hypothesis predicted strong activation (~6.4–6.8) on the 'ung' piece for line-initial "Lung cancer", but the observed activation on 'ung' is only 0.0396 with all other tokens at 0.0000. This shows no collocation boost.

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: REFUTED
Evidence: In "Lung cancer is deadly.", the maximal activation 0.0396 occurs at 'ung', far below the expected high activation for line-initial "Lung cancer", indicating no enhanced response to the collocation.

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.0000
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: 'Hung'=0.0000, 'ary'=0.0000, ' Europe'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
CONFIRM. The hypothesis predicts low activation for non-organ '-ung' substrings. The test sentence produced 0.0000 on 'Hung' (and all other tokens), matching the expected ≈0.0–<0.5 range for generic '-ung' occurrences.

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: CONFIRMED
Evidence: In "Hungary is in Europe.", 'Hung'=0.0000 and all other tokens are 0.0000, demonstrating no activation for the generic '-ung' substring, consistent with H3’s prediction.

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.1406
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: ' lung'=0.1406, 'The'=0.0000, ' cancer'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
REFINE. H4 predicts reduced activation for hyphenated contexts; the observed activation on ' lung' is low (0.1406) with all other tokens at 0.0000, consistent with suppression in “non-small-cell lung cancer.” The magnitude is near-zero, indicating stronger suppression than any moderate level.

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: REFINED
Evidence: In “The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.” the feature shows minimal activation at ' lung' (0.1406), supporting the “hyphenation reduces activation” claim but suggesting the effect is suppressed to near-zero in such structures. Line-initial enhancement is not assessed by this test.

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H1 (REFUTED): 
  Reason: In the test "Lung health matters.", the maximal activation was 0.0396 at 'ung' (BOS=0.0000; ' health'=0.0000), far below the hypothesized strong response (>5) for the “ lung”/“ung” pieces in line-initial “Lung …”.

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: REFUTED
Reason: The single targeted positive case directly contradicts H1’s core prediction (expected >5 vs observed 0.0396 on 'ung'), indicating the feature does not strongly detect “lung”/“Lung” tokens as hypothesized. Corpus coverage check: no ≥10.0 corpus activations to replicate; exemplars (5.594–6.750) were not reproduced by the synthetic test. Critical missing tests remain (e.g., mid-sentence “ lung”, “the lung is”), but the decisive failure on the primary line-initial case justifies refutation.

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H2 (REFUTED):
  Reason: The test "Lung cancer is deadly." produced a maximal activation of 0.0396 at 'ung' (BOS=0.0000; ' cancer'=0.0000), far below the expected ~6.4–6.8 for line-initial “Lung cancer,” contradicting the predicted collocation boost.

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: REFUTED
Reason: The single targeted positive-case test directly contradicts H2’s core prediction (expected strong boost vs 0.0396 observed on 'ung'). Corpus coverage check: No corpus tokens ≥10.0 (top ≈6.75), so coverage criterion is vacuously satisfied (Can conclude: YES). While additional tests (e.g., mid-sentence “ lung” without “cancer”) could further compare baselines, the key claim—that the “lung cancer” collocation boosts activation—was not observed, justifying refutation.

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H3 (REFINED):
  Refined version: The feature does not activate on generic “-ung” substrings (e.g., “Hungary”), showing near-zero activation; there is insufficient evidence that it selectively targets the organ word “lung.”
  Explanation: Test “Hungary is in Europe.” showed max 0.0000 with 'Hung'=0.0000.

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: REFINED
Reason: The single negative-control test aligns with the “non-generic -ung” non-activation prediction (max 0.0000), but provides no positive evidence for selectivity to “lung.” Corpus coverage check: no ≥10.0 corpus tokens (top ≈6.75), so coverage is satisfied. Can conclude overall: NO—critical missing tests include positive cases with “lung” (e.g., “the lung is...”, mid-sentence “ lung”), plurals/synonyms (“lungs”, “pulmonary”), and other generic “-ung” words (“young”, “among”, “plunge”).

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H4 (REFINED):
  Refined version: The feature shows only low activation on the token “ lung” when it appears after complex hyphenated modifiers in oncology phrases (e.g., “non-small-cell lung cancer”), indicating suppression in hyphenated contexts; no evidence yet for line-initial/title-case enhancement.
  Explanation: In “The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.” the maximal activation was 0.1406 at ' lung' (BOS=0.0000; others 0.0000), consistent with suppression to near-zero in hyphenated structures.

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: REFINED
Reason: The single targeted hyphenated case aligns with the “reduced activation under hyphenation” prediction (max 0.1406 at ' lung'), but we lack a complementary positive case (e.g., line-initial/title-case “Lung …”) to test the enhancement claim. Corpus coverage: no ≥10.0 tokens in exemplars (top ≈6.75), so that criterion is met; however, critical tests are missing (line-initial “Lung …”, plain mid-sentence “ lung”, plural “lungs”, synonym “pulmonary”). Conclusion now: NO—additional tests are needed to assess enhancement vs. suppression comprehensively.

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.0000
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: 'Young'=0.0000, ' people'=0.0000, ' quickly'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
CONFIRM. The hypothesis predicts near-zero activation for generic “-ung” substrings; the sentence with “Young” produced 0.0000 on all tokens, matching the expected low response (e.g., 'Young'=0.0000).

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: CONFIRMED
Evidence: The test "Young people learn quickly." shows max 0.0000 with 'Young'=0.0000, consistent with the previous negative-control ("Hungary is in Europe." max 0.0000). Both support that generic “-ung” substrings do not activate this feature.

ANALYSIS:
Summary activation: 0.2891
BOS activation: 0.0000
Top non-BOS tokens: ' lung'=0.2891, 'She'=0.0000, ' cancer'=0.0000

INTERPRETATION:
CONFIRM. In a hyphenated oncology phrase (“small-cell lung cancer”), the feature shows only low activation on ' lung' (0.2891) with all other tokens at 0.0000, consistent with suppression in hyphenated contexts. This aligns with the prior hyphenated case (0.1406 at ' lung').

UPDATED HYPOTHESIS STATUS:
Hypothesis: CONFIRMED
Evidence: Low activations on ' lung' in hyphenated contexts across two tests: 0.1406 (“non-small-cell lung cancer”) and 0.2891 (“small-cell lung cancer”), supporting the suppression claim; no evidence yet for line-initial/title-case enhancement.

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H3 (CONFIRMED):
  Evidence: Two negative-control tests with generic “-ung” substrings showed no activation: 
    • "Hungary is in Europe." → max 0.0000; 'Hung'=0.0000
    • "Young people learn quickly." → max 0.0000; 'Young'=0.0000

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: CONFIRMED
Reason: Both tests align with the hypothesis that generic “-ung” substrings do not activate this feature (all tokens 0.0000). Corpus coverage check: no ≥10.0 tokens in exemplars (top ≈6.75), so criterion is met; while other generic “-ung” words (e.g., among, plunge) could be tested, the consistent zero activations across two distinct cases provide sufficient evidence to confirm H3’s claim about non-activation on generic “-ung” substrings.

HYPOTHESIS UPDATES:
- H4 (CONFIRMED):
  Evidence: "The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer." → max 0.1406 at ' lung' (others 0.0000); "She was diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer." → max 0.2891 at ' lung' (others 0.0000). Both low, confirming suppression in hyphenated oncology contexts.

STATUS ASSESSMENT:
Current Status: CONFIRMED
Reason: Two independent hyphenated phrases produce only low activation on ' lung' (0.1406, 0.2891) with all other tokens 0.0000, consistent with the refined claim of suppression under hyphenation. Corpus coverage: no ≥10.0 tokens in exemplars (top ≈6.75), so coverage criterion is met. Remaining untested aspects (line-initial/title-case enhancement, plain non-hyphenated “ lung”, plurals/synonyms) do not affect confirmation of the suppression claim.

REVIEW SUMMARY:
- H1: REFUTED based on one test showing near-zero activation on 'ung' for line-initial "Lung …" (0.0396).
- H2: REFUTED based on one test; line-initial "Lung cancer …" showed near-zero activation on 'ung' (0.0396), no collocation boost observed.
- H3: CONFIRMED with two negative controls; generic “-ung” substrings (Hungary, Young) produce 0.0000 activation.
- H4: CONFIRMED for suppression in hyphenated oncology contexts; two tests show low activation on ' lung' (0.1406, 0.2891).

ASSESSMENT:
- Not all hypotheses are adequately tested. H1 and H2 each have only one test and contradict corpus exemplars showing high activations near “lung/Lung”.
- Gaps: No test for plain mid-sentence “ lung” without hyphenation; no replication of exemplar-style title phrase (“Lung Cancer Causes Without Smoking”); no simple baseline “He has lung cancer.”; no mid-sentence plain “lung” (e.g., “The lung is vital.”).
- No direct contradictions between confirmed hypotheses (H3, H4) and refuted ones (H1, H2); rather, current tests suggest context sensitivity not yet probed.

DECISION:
Need more testing: YES
- H1: "The lung is vital."
- H1: "He studied lung physiology."
- H2: "Lung cancer kills thousands."
- H2: "He developed lung cancer."
- H2: "Lung Cancer Causes Without Smoking"
- H4: "He has lung cancer."
- H4: "They treat non small cell lung cancer."

REVIEW SUMMARY:
- H1: REFUTED. Initial claim of strong activation on “lung/Lung” (>5) does not hold; line-initial “Lung …” yields ~0.04, while mid-sentence “ lung” shows only modest activation (≈1.3–1.7).
- H2: REFUTED. No collocation boost for “Lung cancer …” at line start (≈0.04); mid-sentence “ lung cancer” yields modest activation on “ lung” (≈1.3–2.5) but not higher than plain “lung.”
- H3: CONFIRMED. Generic “-ung” substrings (Hungary, Young) show 0.0000 activation.
- H4: CONFIRMED (suppression pattern). Hyphenated oncology modifiers show low activation on “ lung” (0.14–0.29); simple “lung cancer” shows higher but still modest activation (2.53).

ASSESSMENT:
- Not all hypotheses are fully stress-tested for morphology/case. H1/H2 are refuted, but additional tests can clarify case sensitivity (lowercase sentence-initial “lung”) and morphology (plural “lungs”, synonym “pulmonary”) to finalize the feature’s scope.
- Gaps: No tests for plural “lungs” or synonym “pulmonary”. Limited probing of sentence-initial lowercase “lung” (tokenization may differ from space-prefixed “ lung”).
- No contradictions: H3’s non-activation on generic “-ung” aligns with H1/H2 refutations and H4 suppression behavior.

DECISION:
Need more testing: YES
- H1: "lung function tests."
- H4: "The lungs are vital."
- H4: "Pulmonary disease is common."

REVIEW SUMMARY:
- H1: REFUTED. Strong activation on “lung/Lung” (>5) not observed; mid-sentence “ lung” shows only modest activation (≈1.3–2.5), line-initial “Lung …” near zero.
- H2: REFUTED. No collocation boost for line-initial “Lung cancer …” (≈0.04); mid-sentence “ lung cancer” yields modest activation on “ lung” (≈1.3–2.5), not exceeding plain “lung.”
- H3: CONFIRMED. Generic “-ung” substrings (Hungary, Young) produce 0.0000 activation; supports non-generic selectivity.
- H4: CONFIRMED (suppression pattern). Hyphenated modifiers yield low “ lung” activation (0.14–0.29); simple “lung cancer” higher (up to 2.53). Plural “lungs” ≈0; synonym “pulmonary” shows notable activation (2.28).

ASSESSMENT:
- Not all hypotheses are fully characterized. H1/H2 have enough to refute the original claims, but additional tests can better map the feature’s scope (mid-sentence vs title-case; morphology and synonyms).
- Gaps: No test for another plain mid-sentence “ lung” variant for H1; limited generic “-ung” coverage (only Hungary/Young) for H3; for H4, need un-hyphenated “small cell lung cancer” (already tested once with all zeros—replicate) and more synonym/plural checks to solidify suppression vs selectivity.
- No contradictions between hypotheses; patterns suggest the feature responds moderately to mid-sentence “ lung,” is suppressed by hyphenation and pluralization, ignores generic “-ung,” and also responds to “pulmonary.”

DECISION:
Need more testing: YES
- H1: "We examine lung anatomy."
- H3: "They plunge into water."
- H4: "small cell lung cancer."
- H4: "Pulmonary embolism is fatal."
- H4: "His lungs collapsed."

REVIEW SUMMARY:
- H1: REFUTED. No strong activation for “lung/Lung” (>5). Mid-sentence “ lung” shows modest activation (1.31–2.73), line-initial “Lung …” and string-initial “lung …” near zero.
- H2: REFUTED. No collocation boost for line-initial “Lung cancer …” (~0.04). Mid-sentence “ lung cancer” activates on “ lung” modestly (1.31–2.53), not exceeding plain “lung.”
- H3: CONFIRMED. Generic “-ung” substrings (Hungary, Young, plunge) yield 0.0000 activation; aligns with non-generic selectivity.
- H4: CONFIRMED (suppression pattern). Hyphenated/non-head contexts yield low “ lung” activation (0.00–0.29). Singular unhyphenated “ lung” in simple clauses activates (2.53). Plural “lungs” is 0.00. “Pulmonary” activates on “monary” (~2.28).

ASSESSMENT:
- Hypotheses are adequately tested to address their specific claims: H1/H2 consistently refuted across multiple cases; H3 confirmed by three distinct generic “-ung” controls; H4 confirmed by nine tests showing suppression under hyphenation/pluralization and moderate activation for singular “ lung” and “pulmonary.”
- Gaps: While broader pulmonary lexicon (respiratory, bronchial, alveoli) could further map the feature’s scope, these are beyond the current hypotheses’ claims.
- No contradictions between hypotheses; patterns cohere: the feature responds to pulmonary-domain tokens (space “ lung”, “monary”), is insensitive to title-case “Lung” BPE “ung,” ignores generic “-ung,” and is suppressed by hyphenation/pluralization.

DECISION:
Need more testing: NO
Explanation: Each hypothesis has sufficient targeted evidence (H1/H2 refuted across multiple contexts; H3 confirmed by multiple negative controls; H4 confirmed by varied morphological/structural cases). Current evidence is adequate to proceed to final conclusions for Feature 97664.

[DESCRIPTION]: 
Feature 97664 activates on pulmonary-domain lexemes in running text, especially the space-prefixed token “ lung” (lowercase, mid-sentence) and the subword “monary” in “pulmonary.” Activations are moderate (≈1.31–2.73 for “ lung”; ≈2.28 for “monary”), while structurally marked forms are suppressed: hyphenated oncology modifiers (“small-/non-small-cell lung cancer”) are low (≈0.00–0.29), plural “lungs” is 0.00, line-initial/title-case “Lung …” (BPE “ung”) is ≈0.04, and string-initial lowercase “lung …” is ≈0.01. Generic “-ung” substrings (e.g., “Hungary,” “Young,” “plunge”) show 0.00, indicating specificity to pulmonary lexemes rather than the character sequence “ung.”

[EVIDENCE]:
- Test 18: 'We examine lung anatomy.' → 2.7344 at ' lung' (supports H4: mid-sentence “ lung” activation)
- Test 13: 'He has lung cancer.' → 2.5312 at ' lung' (supports H4: unhyphenated “ lung” activation)
- Test 17: 'Pulmonary disease is common.' → 2.2812 at 'monary' (supports H4: activation on “pulmonary”)
- Test 21: 'Pulmonary embolism is fatal.' → 2.2812 at 'monary' (supports H4: replication on “pulmonary”)
- Test 8: 'The lung is vital.' → 1.6016 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 9: 'He studied lung physiology.' → 1.6797 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 11: 'He developed lung cancer.' → 1.3125 at ' lung' (supports H4)
- Test 4: 'The patient had non-small-cell lung cancer.' → 0.1406 at ' lung' (supports H4: hyphenation suppression)
- Test 6: 'She was diagnosed with small-cell lung cancer.' → 0.2891 at ' lung' (supports H4: hyphenation suppression)
- Test 20: 'small cell lung cancer.' → 0.0532 at ' lung' (supports H4: modifier suppression)
- Test 14: 'They treat non small cell lung cancer.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: modifier suppression)
- Test 16: 'The lungs are vital.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: plural suppression)
- Test 22: 'His lungs collapsed.' → 0.0000 (supports H4: plural suppression)
- Test 15: 'lung function tests.' → 0.0063 at 'lung' (refutes H1: string-initial lowercase “lung” weak)
- Tests 1/2/7/10/12: line-initial/title-case “Lung …” → 0.0396 at 'ung' (refutes H1/H2: no boost at “Lung” start)
- Test 3: 'Hungary is in Europe.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)
- Test 5: 'Young people learn quickly.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)
- Test 19: 'They plunge into water.' → 0.0000 (supports H3: generic “-ung” ignored)

[LABEL 1]: Pulmonary lexemes in running text: space-prefixed “ lung” (lowercase, mid-sentence) OR “pulmonary” (“-monary” subword), with suppression for hyphenated modifiers, plural “lungs,” and title-/string-initial forms; ignores generic “-ung” substrings.
